Award.AwardTitle: What is Aquaporin-1's role in transport across large vessels walls?
Award.AbstractNarration: Blood pressure drives fluid containing water and solutes across the walls of large arteries. Although the arterial wall is composed of several layers, the innermost layer (blood side) is composed of a single layer of cells (endothelial cells). Blocking aquaporin-1, a protein that allows water to pass through the endothelial cells, decreases fluid flow across the wall. Unexpectedly, the level of this reduction depends on the blood pressure. This project will develop a mathematical theory to explain the contribution of these aquaporins to the microanatomy of the vessel wall, including this pressure-dependence, and to the flow and transport through it. Additionally, the project will test the theory's predictions with experiments on rat vessels and on cultured cells. It will also test the hypothesis that a vessel can actively change its number of aquaporins in response to changes in blood pressure and see how these changes affect flow across the vessel wall. Because fluid flow can affect the deposition of cholesterol in the arterial wall, this research will provide a fundamental understanding of the earliest events leading to hardening of the arteries. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in this research. Under the guidance of the principal investigator, undergraduate students will conduct outreach activities at local high schools to stimulate the high school students' interest in the integration of the physical sciences with the biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Blood pressure drives liquid and solutes from the blood slowly through the artery wall. One such solute, LDL-cholesterol, can bind to wall constituents, which can lead to hardening of the arteries. Our preliminary and more recent data show that the endothelial cells (ECs) lining the artery wall express a membrane protein, aquaporin1, that allows pure water to pass through as well as around the cells. Plugging these aquaporins or lowering their numbers (with siRNA) lowers water flow through the wall, but, surprisingly, this lowering is far more drastic at 60 than at 100 or 140mmHg; it would be pressure-independent for simple materials.

            Earlier we showed that increasing pressure compresses the sparse (subendothelial intima – SI) layer just beneath the endothelium up to a maximum value. At sufficient compression, ECs block the fenestraal holes leading to the rest of the wall (the media), which significantly increases vessel wall flow resistance. Thus the hydraulic conductivity, Lp, the ratio of water flux to driving pressure is flat at low pressures (and inverse of a resistance), drops rapidly over a narrow pressure regime where the ECs start to block fenestrae, and then assume a new, lower plateau beyond maximal compression. We showed that reduction in functioning aquaporin1 is consistent with a shift to lower pressures of the pressure range over which the SI compresses and Lp drops. We have developed a fluid mechanics theory that explains the above pressure-dependence. The idea is analogous to two sailboats, one with an intact sail and one with a sail with holes, in the same wind. the boat whose sail has holes moves slower since the wind has a harder time establishing a pressure difference across the sail to drive the boat. Similarly, the endothelium with more functioning aquaporins sees a smaller force across its endothelium than one with fewer functioning aquaporins and therefore requires a larger blood pressure to achieve the critical transendothelial force/area to compress the SI and lower Lp. Blocking aquaporins moves this drop from above to below 60 mmHg. Our theory predicts that increasing functioning EC aquaporin1 shifts the critical pressure to higher pressures, and into the physiological regime, thereby decompressing the SI and drastically increasing (~ 50%) trans-wall water flow. This can potentially dilute solute, e.g., LDL-cholesterol, in the SI, slow its rate of getting stuck and wash unbound solute from the wall. We shall test this prediction in the next grant.

            Since aquaporin1 allows essentially only pure water and no solutes to pass, it would seem that small solutes would build up on the blood side and be strongly diluted on the SI side of the EC. The resulting osmotic/oncotic difference should oppose the pressure and suck liquid back from the SI to the blood, in contrast to observation. We have developed a fluid mechanics/ mass transfer theory that explains this paradox. The key point the model has taught us is that, the far denser media acts like a coffee filter that accumulates oncotic solvents that enter the SI around the ECs in the media and SI. So, instead of being more dilute, the Si is more concentrated than the blood side of the EC and the oncotic difference sucks water from the blood into the SI, not the other way, and the transendotheial trans-aquaporin1 flow can persist.
